edu.uncc.cs.bridges

Class GraphVisualizer<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.uncc.cs.bridges.Visualizer
      • edu.uncc.cs.bridges.GraphVisualizer<T>
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Queue, Stack

    public class GraphVisualizer<T>
extends Visualizer
    Object Oriented Graph Visualizer intended to be used like: OOVisual v = new OOVisual();
    v.add("actor/Tom Hanks");
    v.get("actor/Tom Hanks).setColor("green");
    Node n = v.get("actor/Tom Hanks");
    n.setColor("blue");
    n.setSize(8.0);
    n.connect("movie/Big").setDashArray("5,5,5");
    Link n = n.get("movie/Big").setWidth("5,5,5");
    v.has("actor/Thorin Oakinshield");

      java.util.Map<java.lang.String,AbstractVertex<T>> vertices

        public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,AbstractVertex<T>> vertices

    • Method Detail

      • getRepresentation

        protected java.lang.String getRepresentation()
        Internal API for exporting visualizer state The end result should look like this: (the source code may have better formatting) {"name": "edu.uncc.cs.bridges", "version": "0.4.0", "visual": "graph", "nodes": [ NODE, NODE, .. NODE ], "links": [ LINK, LINK, .. LINK ] } Where NODE and LINK have basically the same syntax: NODE = LINK = { "\w+": ANY_JSON_TYPE, .. } Note how there is no trailing comma in lists.
        Specified by:
        getRepresentation in class Visualizer
